comments:
I noticed this in latest builds from the 1.5 stream (I200601270511), not sure if it also happens in previous builds.

Opening a jsp file in the editor causes eclipse to freeze for several seconds (from 10 sec. to more than one minute). The GUI becomes totally irresponsive.
I noticed this with jsp files with standard (non xml) syntax.

Could be related to http requests for fetching taglibraries dtd. If I try running eclipse using the com.ibm.etools.www.protocol.http.Handler I see LOTS (at least a couple for each jsp file) of recurring records while opening jsp files like:

URL requested : http://java.sun.com/dtd/web-jsptaglibrary_1_2.dtd
URL mapped    : (not mapped)

The dtd is cached, and I tried also mapping the public URI to a local file, but without any effect. Maybe internet cache or xml catalogs are not used properly here??

<ping> did anyone had a chance to review this?
The report has been submitted 9 days ago and it's still in the inbox: the performance problem described is really critical when working with jsp files. If there is really a problem with fetching of dtds this should probably be addressed before 1.0.1

Nitin looks related to taglib indexing/TLDCMDocument getting built...?

Fabrizio what are some of the properties of the JSP file?

 - size of the JSP
 - how many different tag libraries are referenced

I tested w/ some simple struts examples and performance seems OK.

I had this problem with very small jsps (20-30 lines), usually with 2 tag libraries declared.

Every time I open a jsp I see 2 requests for dtd files from the sun website caught from the trace tool: also if performance looks not bad on your example can you check if these dtds are fetched also in your case? Am I wrong or, if the code reach that java.net.URL.openConnection() cache and locally mapped files are not used?
If cache is really not used this should be fixed: maybe you are not seeing performance problems because your connection to the sun website is faster than mine ;)

> attempts to load any entities like the DTD should fail outright.
> Unfortunately we can't call out to the caching resolver during this code path
> since it's a critical model-loading case in which we have to avoid deadlocks.

If so, what about setting a dummy entity resolver for the xml parser and making it ignore (returning an empty stream) any external dtd/entity? If this is not going to cause problems elsewhere it's an easy patch that could dramatically improve performance...
Fabrizio, a behind-the-scenes fallback would have been my next guess:)  I've committed code to 1.5 that ensures that an InputSource is always returned so that the fallback-default will not be called.

This bug is being moved to the "closed" state since it has been in the fixed state for a so long it is being assumed fixed, without explicit verification from the originator. If there is still a problem, in the most recent 1.5.x builds, please reopen or open another bug.
